captions.text:
What’s happenin yo? This week on
Thug Notes we gettin regal with Hamlet by William Shakespeare

Da shit’s gone wack up in the
kingdom of Elsinore. The old King’s brother

Claudius gone and married the king’s old
breezy Gertrude, and Queen Gertrude’s son

Hamlet gettin all crunk since his mama actin
like a ho.

Things get straight stupid when
some guards peep the ghost of the old King

Hamlet creepin up on the castle. Then them
guards holler at Hamlet and tell him he gotta
check this ghost.

So Hamlet step up to his ghost
daddy who tell him that his brotha Claudius

was plottin on the crown and straight iced
his ass cold blooded. Ghost daddy tell Hamlet

that he gotta strap up and put a toe tag on
that fool Claudius. Street justice, naw mean?

Back in the castle, Hamlet’s boo
Ophelia gettin an earful from her daddy Polonius

and her brotha Laertes. They say she need
to steer clear of Hamlet since he might just

hit it and quit it. Ophelia says “good lookin
out” and ignores all of Hamlet’s hollerin.

So when Hamet actin cray-cray at the thought
of glocking Claudius, errybody just think
he love-sick.

Later, Hamlet decides he gonna put
on a play that reenacts how Claudius ghosted
the old King.

When Claudius sees his crime
happenin on stage, he books it for the exit.

Now Hamlet knows FO SHO ghost-daddy been spittin
the truth.

Later, Hammy rolls up to his mama’s
crib where she aks him why he be disrespectin

the king. All the while, Polonius be hiding
listening in. When Hamlet and Gertrude get

all up in eachother’s grill, Polonious screams
like a bitch. Thinkin it’s that fool Claudius,

Hamlet shanks that cat right through the
curtain.

Now Laertes gettin crunk about
Hamlet killin his father, and Ophelia starts

losing her shit. So Claudius comes up with
a plan that Laertes should dip his sword’s

tip in poison and challenge Hamlet to a duel.
And if that don’t work, Claudius gonna put

some poison in Hamlet’s wine. Shit gets
even more real when the Queen busts in and
says Ophelia dun drowned!

As Laertes and Hamlet bang out, the
queen toasts to Hamlet but accidentally slams

some o dat poison joose. Then Laertes and
Hamlet both stab eachother with dat poison
blade.

Just then, Gertrude bites the dust
and Laertes starts snitchin to Hamlet how

Claudius be trying to poison him. So Hamlet
stabs Claudius AND makes him drink from that
poison cup. Mmmm. Elizabethan haterade. Gotta have it.

In the end, the royal family all
layin in chalk, so the kingdom goes to some
other soldier boy named Fortinbras.

Now all throughout this play Hamlet
be all torn up bout the task of puttin one

in Claudius’s dome, and keeps delayin’.
His procrastination is one of the most debated
subjects in all of Shakespeare.

Some ballas think it’s because
Hamlet be too much of a sensitive bitch to

kick it in a world of gangstas playin dirty
on tha street. Others thinkin that Hamlet

got mad Oedipal Complex all up in this motherfucker.
Since Hamlet wanna get freaky with his mama,

he can’t bring himself to gat the man who
doin what he wanna do: kill his pop and get

down with his old lady. Some cats even think
that Hamlet just trying to buck the system

and bring down a crooked kingdom overflowin
with lies and treachery.

And speakin of lies, you might have
spotted our bard Willy Shakes slingin images

of skin disease all up in this heezy. When
Hamlet dissin his mama in Act 3, he be talkin

bout the body and soul’s “ulcerous places”
and “blisters”. And, in 5.1 the clown-gravediggers

be yappin about pocky corpses. All this nasty
ass sh*t showin how although these fools be

frontin lookin righteous, they aint got nothing
but ruin and corruption underneath.

Now you just ain’t goin hard in the
paint unless you realize how this play captures

the ambiguity of modernity. Like the modern
man, Hamlet ain’t got a clear devotion to

a code. In fact Hamlet be trippin up cuz of
his divided mind and will. How’s a brotha

gonna keep it real on the streets with all
these ethical and metaphysical uncertainties,
my man?

We peepin that uncertainty in my
boy’s famous “to be or not to be” speech.

Some OGs think this speech mean Hamlet can’t
decide whether he wanna live or die. But my

other brothas think that he trying to chose
between the Christian ideal of denyin the
self or spillin some blood to claim his throne.

But Hamlet ain’t the only one who be confused.
In the play of life, the bard gone and even

cast us as
characters of uncertainty. I mean, check all

thee uncertainties, playa: “Can we really
trust Hamlet’s ghost daddy? Was Gertrude

in on the whole thing? Can errybody see the
ghost in Act 1 but only my boy Hamlet

in Act 3? Is Hamlet just pretending to be
crazy? Or has his mad fiction become fact?

Looks like Ol’ Willy’s gone and made Hamlets
of us all.

Yo I hope you feelin educated
today, playa. Tune in next week!

title: Hamlet - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.author: Caitlin Eisner

comments.text:
+Caitlin Eisner The analysis in this video sparks some interesting thought 
provoking questions about being true to self. Also, I find it appealing how 
Shakespeare left a lot of these decisions up to us, the reader, to 
interpret. What's unique about the play of Hamlet is not only the ambiguity 
of it all, but how throughout the whole play Hamlet is much like us, 
continuing to question reality. What is true is the mind's own perception, 
but deciding what to believe is the tough choice we all decide to make 
daily.

comments.text:
I absolutely adore Thug Notes, but it's wildly inappropriate to show 
Hamlet's pondering suicide in To Be Or Not To Be by stereotyping him as 
"emo" with coloured hair, eyeliner and slit wrists (4:11). Please show some 
respect for both the writing and those who struggle with mental illness and 
thoughts of suicide without condemning them to a disgusting stereotype.﻿

comments.author: Fu_manschue

comments.text:
+supermanwithabeard03
Haha that's cool- I actually like your rant! I completely understand where 
you're coming from, mate. I understand that a large part of people's 
dislike for Shakespeare comes from their being forced to read it, and I can 
certainly see how a teacher using outdated material is off-putting. That 
sucks. :/ I never hated Shakespeare, but I never understood why learning 
about his works was so important...until I began studying theatre. Ha. 
Given that he's a cornerstone of the theatre world/education...kinda 
happens. But, I did not understand the language until I was IN a play. I 
played Hermia in "A Midsummer Night's Dream," and one day the switch 
flipped on...and it was wonderful. I was so happy that I could suddenly 
understand everything that was written on the page and how to translate it, 
speak it, perform it... I don't think teachers (at least that I've heard 
of) can really teach it outside of a theatrical context, unfortunately. 

I understand it's hard to overcome, but I still think you should try a bit 
harder...if for no other reason than to get a good grade in the class. Is 
your main issue that you struggle to understand the language or is it 
something else? Have you used Sparknotes? I actually wrote *nearly* the 
same essay this time last year for an assignment.

Mine was a bit more complex, though...it was a critical analysis of Hamlet 
and how it has influenced artists, musicians, poets, etc. through the ages. 
The idea came about from Jim Morrison's poem "Ode to LA while thinking of 
Brian Jones, deceased." It was interesting to write...definitely a 
challenge but I felt pretty good about it. It does explore the theme of the 
Oedipal complex as well. If you think it might help you, I'd be more than 
happy to send it your way. :) 

I've only read a bit of HST, but my mother adores him, and I know enough 
about his work to know he was brilliant. :) And everyone knows the 
drugged-up/alcoholic/mentally ill fucked up artists are always the best 
ones!! (Hence why I occasionally sit down and question how successful of an 
actor I can really be, since I've had a pretty good life...lol.) I don't 
believe I've ever read anything by Charles Bukowski, but the name is 
familiar. 

Lastly, I don't know where you're from and if a lot of theatre happens 
there, BUT if you ever get the chance to see the play "Equivocation" by 
Bill Cain, please please PLEASE do so. One of the most incredible fucking 
plays I've ever seen. I would summarize it for you but I've already written 
a freakin' book here, haha. But, it is about Shakespeare, to put it simply.
And it's all in modern language. ;)

ALSO if you have time or are just bored one day, I highly recommend Julie 
Taymor's film of Shakespeare's tragedy  "Titus Andronicus" (this version 
only titled "Titus") it was highly influential in changing my mind about 
Shakespeare as well. The full film is on youtube, you just have to watch it 
in parts which is annoying but definitely worth it. :) Have a great night 
and best of luck on your essay!
comments.author: Ashley Miller

comments.text:
+Ashley Miller I hear you. I love to read, but my unremitting lack of a 
shit to give about Shakespeare is too strong to overcome. I'd rather put 
forth efforts into reading Hunter S. Thompson, Charles Bukowski and other 
more contemporary authors (of course, you could argue that Thompson was 
nothing more than a drug addled journalist and Bukowski was a sot, but to 
me they are a hell of a lot more intriguing than Shakespeare, not to 
mention more topical, relevant and, if I were teaching a literature class, 
I'd much rather have my students read the works of HST and Bukowski than 
Shakespeare -- I reckon they'd find it more engrossing). Why am I here? 
This year, I went back to college after being away for five years. The 
semester is coming to a close and I need to write a proctored essay about 
Hamlet and Oedipus Rex tomorrow. My extreme disinterest is so apparent. 
This English class is online, and the instructor uses videos from the '60s 
and '70s and lecture videos of his own from 1997. It's... disingenuous and 
fails to engage the student. Now I'm getting off-topic. Whatever. I just 
wanted to rant! :)
comments.author: supermanwithabeard03

comments.text:
This is a crash course. It gives you the basics and the most important 
parts, but you shouldn't substitute it from learning from the source 
material and getting the full story. Once you are able to understand 
Shakes, it's very rewarding and deeply fulfilling to learn.

comments.text:
There are good intentions behind these videos, some people may learn a lot 
about the book, which ever it may be, and people might relate to the way 
things are said in these videos or it may help them learn about the book 
more by using the "modern" language. But I think that there is to much 
cussing and hard to understand some of the phrases that are said because 
they are not used in the correct way. I loved the play Hamlet, but I did 
not like this video. The things that the guy says about some of the events 
in the play are not completely correct and the intentions of the characters 
are not exactly what he says in these videos. These videos may help some 
people but I found it completely pointless.﻿

comments.text:
i feel like one of the most important aspects of hamlet (and perhaps this 
is just my interpretation) is about mortality. like what the hell is the 
point of living if we are all going to turn to dust at the end of it, 
especially if life is shrouded in tragedy. hamlet is isolated because 
almost everyone in his kingdom is really fucking stupid and he doesn't see 
the point of living. i think hamlet's desire to cease to live is one of the 
most important character traits he possesses and was only briefly touched 
on in these notes, though they were good notes.﻿
